repnme.cdata!:
Zimbabwe - Urban Sector and Regional
            Development Project and Rural District Council Pilot Capital
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Sector and Regional
            Development Project's overall outcome is rated as
            moderately satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as modest, Bank performance
            as satisfactory, and Borrower performance as satisfactory.
            The Rural District Council Pilot Capital Development
            Project's overall outcome is rated as unsatisfactory,
            sustainability as unlikely, institutional development impact
            as modest, Bank performance as satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance as unsatisfactory. The performance of both
            projects was strongly affected by Zimbabwe's historic
            distortions of spatial segregation along racial lines in
            both urban and rural areas, and the government's
            fast-tracked land reform efforts designed to deal with them.
            A sudden shift of borrower policy can undermine the project
            results. Some OED lessons with these projects include: a) A
            one-size-fits-all approach to urban project design should
            give way to a design firmly anchored to the particular
            conditions of a borrower's cities and urban
            development. b) Project objective statements should clearly
            signal intended development results.

1942062.trustfund:
TF027024-PHRD - LOCAL GOVERNMENT
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF032183-ZIMBABWE - URBAN DEVELOPMENT

repnme.cdata!:
Zimbabwe - Urban Sector and Regional
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Sector and Regional
            Development Project was considered satisfactory in the
            achievement of its objectives and its outcome. The lessons
            learned include the following: 1) The appropriateness of a
            Project Implementation Unit outside of the civil service
            structure is based on considering the long-term development
            role of the project's implementation arrangements, and
            the need for inter-ministerial coordination and
            collaboration in implementing the project's development
            objectives. 2) The Public Sector Investment Program (PSIP)
            was the key source of counterpart funding under the project.
            A key lessons learned is that the mixing of fiscal and
            financial policies of central government in
            intergovernmental relations is not sustainable and not
            desirable in implementation of sound decentralization
            policy. 3) Local government projects needs to recognize the
            diversity of local capacity and to include mechanisms to
            improve this capacity. 4) The role of a central ministry
            responsible for local government policies should result in a
            policy shift from an emphasis on "command and
            control" to more devolution. 5) Networking and
            dissemination have proved to be very important and
            effective. 6) Fiscal and financial instruments for support
            to local government need to be carefully separated, with
            appropriate policy and implementation arrangements being
            formulated and implemented.

5077510.trustfund:
TF022315-INTERNSHIP PROG FOR SOUTH
            AFRICANS AT THE WORLD BANK

repnme.cdata!:
Zimbabwe - Urban Sector and Regional
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is structured as a sector
            loan under which the Government will undertake to appraise
            individual projects in urban areas based on criteria
            acceptable to both the Government and the Bank.
            Specifically, the project will: (i) support the provision of
            primary urban infrastructure, including water supply,
            sewerage, and roads and drainage, as well as provide for
            maintenance of related vehicles and equipment; (ii) support
            the provision of urban housing for 500,000 people under the
            next 5 year capital development plan; (iii) introduce a
            regional development strategy, a corridor town development
            plan, and district development investment plans; and (iv)
            strengthen the institutional capacity of central government
            to appraise proposed projects, and local authorities to
            perform their functions.

Zimbabwe - Urban Sector and Regional
